section1.p: is a tool that works as a utility in (aka ). runs the program followed by the program on a text or a portion of a text that exists in a project. You tell the rule file to use as well as an input control file. Then you can choose a text or a portion of that text and ask to process it. The result will show in the same as it does when using either of the two morphological parsers that come with .

The input to the program is the same as what uses for the default morphological parser (which is ). This means that you must control using the capabilities offers, not what you may have used with via, say, .
works with version or higher of and is only available on 64-bit Windows computers.

section2.p: To install , obtain the installer from https://​github.com/​sillsdev/​pcpatrflex/​blob/​ToneParsFLEx/​InstallerTonePars/​Output/​UseToneParsWithFLExDllSetup.exe. The installer will check to see if you have installed version 9. If not, it will abort.
We recommend that you close before running the installer.
While running , use Tools menu item / Utilities.... Find the “Use TonePars with FLEx” item, check it, and then click on the “Run Checked Utilities Now” button.
The first time you invoke on a database, it will automatically add to your database the following:

ol.li: a custom field to each sense (called “ToneParsSense”);

a custom field for each allomorph/lexeme form
The current version of does not show this custom field on Lexeme Form. You can set it, though, by swapping the lexeme form with an allomorph. See the help system for how to do this. (called “ToneParsForm”); and
a custom list (called “TonePars Properties”). You use this custom list to create any allomorph or morpheme properties used in your rule file.

section2.p: The names shown above are always in the English analysis writing system and English is the only writing system containing these names.
You can find the custom list by clicking on the “Lists” button in .
looks like what is shown in .
The texts in the database are shown in the left pane and the segments of the first text are shown in the right pane.
There are buttons you can click. Each is discussed in section below.

section1.p: You control by using the various buttons and check boxes. This section briefly describes them.

section2.p: To choose which rule file to use, click on the topmost Browse button. By convention, rule files have an extension of “.ctl” so this is what the file browser uses.

section2.secTitle: AMPLE intx ctl file Browse button
section2.p: As you most likely already know, when using , one first parses a text via but as part of the processing, strips out tone marking. The result is then passed to . In order to correctly strip out the tone markings, needs to know the location of the input text control file needed. To choose which input text control file to use, click on the Browse button. By convention, input text control file names end with “intx.ctl” so this is what the file browser uses.

The next item is a check box with a label of “Trace Tone Processing.” When working with , you often need to get a trace of what the tool is doing. When this check box is checked, invokes with tracing turned on. The log file will show the results of the tracing process. See section for the various tracing options available and see section for how to see the resulting log file.
When you click on the “Tracing Options” button, it brings up a dialog box that looks like what is in example :
The options listed are the same as the options available in .
When you click on the “Show Log” button, the log file generated by the last invocation of will be displayed.

section2.secTitle: Verify Control File Information check box
section2.p: One run time option for is to verify various pieces of information. When the “Verify Control File Information’ check box is checked, will invoke in such a way that this information will be included in the log file. You can see it by showing the log file (see section ).
The “Help...” button is used to get this user documentation file, show the TonePars Manual, show the TonePars Grammar documentation file, or show the “About” dialog box.

Above the pane containing the texts is a button labeled “Parse this text.” You use this button to parse this entire text via and then . The mouse icon will change to the “busy” shape until it is done. The results will show in the same way as using one of the morphological parsers that come with show their result. It is easiest to see this in the “Texts & Words" / “Interlinear Texts" view or the “Texts & Words" / “Word Analyses” view.

Above the pane containing the segments of the selected text is a button labeled “Parse this segment.” You use this button to parse this particular segment via and then . The mouse icon will change to the “busy” shape until it is done. The results will show in the same way as using one of the morphological parsers that come with show their result. It is easiest to see this in the “Texts & Words" / “Interlinear Texts" view or the “Texts & Words" / “Word Analyses” view.

section1.p: Whenever you exit and restart , it will do the following:

ol.li: remember the size and position of the window;
remember which rule file you last chose;
remember which intx ctl file you last chose;
remember the settings of “Trace Tone Processing,” “Tracing Options.” and “Verify Control File Information;”
remember which text in that project you last selected; and
remember which segment in that text you last selected.

section1.p: The following items are known to be less than desirable with this version of :

ol.li: only works with version or higher of .

If a lexical entry in is marked as either a proclitic or an enclitic, it may not parse correctly. This is because creates two entries for it with the same morphname; one is as an affix and the other is as a root. may not process it correctly due to this ambiguity. It might be possible, however, to model these as affixes instead of as proclitics/ enclitics.

When you need to mark an allomorph with an allomorph property using the custom field of “ToneParsForm,” the custom field only shows up in for an allomorph. It does not show for a lexeme form. To add an allomorph property to a lexeme form, you can use the “Swap Lexeme Form with Allomorph” capability (on the Lexeme Form item) or the “Swap Allomorph with Lexeme Form” capability (on the Allomorph item). See the help system for how to do this.

The current version of does not always parse a capitalized word. Here is one way to try and deal with this:
This is a slightly modified version of Kevin Warfel's work-around in 's issue tracking system at LT-5722.
Go to the Baseline tab and change the upper-case letter to lower case.
Return to the Analyze tab and parse the segment in .
If there are multiple parser-generated analyses available, select the correct one, then click on the green check mark. (This marks that particular analysis as “user-approved” in the Word Analyses area, which the interlinear view uses as one of its default sources.)
Go back to the Baseline tab and change the letter back to upper case.
Return to the Analyze tab, click on the word, then use the drop-down arrow on the Morphemes line to select the lower-case form of the word. (This should enable FLEx to associate the previously generated analysis of the lower-case form with the current instance.)
The user interface is in English only.
Be sure to close *before* you close or there may a version of running in the background. This can prevent from starting again.

produces a copy of the Tone Rule file with an extension of “.hvo” in the directory where the Tone Rule file is. This file is used by in order to correctly handle “morphname is” statements in the rule file.

section1.p: When you parse a segment or a text, produces several temporary files. There may be times when seeing these files will prove useful, especially if you are used to seeing such files in . To see the files, open a Windows Explorer window in the temp directory. One way to do this is to click in the address bar and then replace its contents with “%TEMP%” (without the quotes). Next, view the directory showing details and click on the "Date modified” column header so that the most recently used files are ordered first. The files used by are shown in example below.

tr.td: The analysis data control file used by .
The PC-PATR grammar file used by . (Most likely this file will not make much sense unless you have a lot of experience with PC-PATR grammar files.
The analysis data control file used by .
A file containing the files loaded by .
The ANA file produced by which is used as the input to .
The output ANA file produced by .
The log file produced by . See section for an easier way to see this.
A file containing the files loaded by .

section1.p: Note that most of these files use numbers instead of text for things like morph-names. This is how it needs to be done for to properly process the data.
If you have any questions with or find bugs in it, please send an email to blackhandrew@gmail.com.

types.comment: The following types are provided as pre-set examples. You may well want to create your own types that refer to one or more of these. You do that by typing in the names of the types in the types attribute of your type.
